column1: Semiluki (Russian: Семилуки) is a town and the administrative center of Semiluksky District in Voronezh Oblast
column3: located on the Don River. Population 26

column1: It was founded in 1894 near the Semiluki railway station
column2: which was named after the nearby village. In 1929
column3: the main enterprise of the settlement
column4: a factory of fireproof materials (now JSC "Semiluksky refractory plant")
column6: Semiluki became the administrative center of Semiluksky District. In July 1942
column7: it was occupied by Nazi Germany. It was liberated on January 25
column8: 1943. A factory of fireproof materials was almost completely destroyed by the Nazis. Town status was granted to Semiluki in 1954.

column1: Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: Semiluki serves as the administrative center of Semiluksky District. As an administrative division
column3: it is incorporated within Semiluksky District as Semiluki Urban Settlement. As a municipal division
column4: this administrative unit also has urban settlement status and is a part of Semiluksky Municipal District.

column1: As most other towns in Russia
column2: Semiluki is divided into microdistricts for town planning purposes. The microdistricts bear proper names; however
column3: an informal and traditional system of dividing the town into residential areas also exists. Many such areas also have informal names
column4: and some of those names are used in official documents together with
column8: is commonly known as Pole chudes (lit. the field of wonders).
